newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary's o/n rates rise on reverse repo deals.
newsitem.headline: Hungary's o/n rates rise on reverse repo deals.

text.p: BUDAPEST, August (19) - Hungary's interbank overnight interest rates rose on Tuesday because of reduced market liquidity from funds flowing into reverse repo deals, partly on repo rate cut expectations, dealers said.
"The main cause (of the interest rate rise) was that everybody who could placed all the surplus money into reverse repo deals," said Sandor Tolonics of Commerzbank.
Overnight money traded in a narrow range between 20.125 and 20.375 percent, rising to 20.375 by the end of the session, up from Tuesday's 20.25 percent end.

Traders said substantial funds were placed into one-week reverse repo deals at 20 percent late last week, at the end of the two-week reserve period, when interest rates were at low levels slightly above 19 percent.
They added that strong repo rate cut expectations also encouraged reverse repo deals although part of the market players did not expect rate cuts.
"I am sure that there will be a repo (rate) cut of minimum 0.25 percentage point in the near future," Tolonics said.
